title-group.article-title: Application of Multiscale Amplitude Modulation Features and Fuzzy C-Means to Brain–Computer Interface

article-meta.aff: 1Graduate Institute of Biomedical Informatics, Taipei Medical University, Taiwan

author-notes.corresp: Wei-Yen Hsu, Graduate Institute of Biomedical Informatics, Taipei Medical University, 250 Wu-Xin Street, Taipei 110, Taiwan Email: shenswy@stat.sinica.edu.tw; shen@csie.ncku.edu.tw

abstract.p: This study proposed a recognized system for electroencephalogram (EEG) data classification. In addition to the wavelet-based amplitude modulation (AM) features, the fuzzy c-means (FCM) clustering is used for the discriminant of left finger lifting and resting. The features are extracted from discrete wavelet transform (DWT) data with the AM method. The FCM is then applied to recognize extracted features. Compared with band power features, k-means clustering, and linear discriminant analysis (LDA) classifier, the results indicate that the proposed method is satisfactory in applications of brain–computer interface (BCI).

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
BCI provides an alternative communication channel by directly transmitting messages to computers from the human brain by analyzing the brain’s mental activities. 1
-
5 BCI systems based on single trial EEG signal analysis associated with finger movement have grown rapidly in the last decade. 3 It focuses on discriminating finger movements for EEG analysis using event-related brain potentials (ERPs). It shows that there are special characteristics of event-related desynchronization (ERD) and synchronization (ERS) in mu and beta rhythms over the sensorimotor cortices during mental tasks. 6
,
7

Feature extraction is an important topic that greatly affects the classification rate. All kinds of feature extraction methods have been proposed. Among them, the band power and adaptive autoregressive (AAR) parameter models are popular. 8
-11 Frequency components in alpha and beta bands are predominately involved in mental tasks, 12 so feature extraction based on band power estimation is usually obtained by computing their powers at these bands. The estimated band powers are then computed with their logarithm values as descriptive parameters for every channel, 8 or estimated by averaging them. 9 On the other hand, AAR models are also common in feature extraction of mental tasks. 10,11 EEG signals are modeled as filtered white noise with certain preferred energy bands by the all-pole AAR model. The AAR model can be intuitively rephrased in the frequency domain as white noise source driving an all-pole spectral shaping network. 13 In this study, we use Daubechies DWT to decompose EEG signals into sub-bands and then to obtain multiresolution envelope features by AM methods. In addition to multiscale characteristics, the features also contain important envelope information.

EEG data classified by supervised classifiers have been applied in many BCI systems. Parameters need to be trained before the applications. FCM clustering, an unsupervised approach, partitions a collection of feature vectors into a number of subgroups based on minimizing the trace of a within-cluster scatter matrix. 14
,
15 The EEG data are nonstationary and their characteristics vary with time. Unsupervised FCM clustering may be better than conventional supervised classifiers in BCI applications since the former does not need training. Several properties of FCM clustering are described. FCM can discriminate the data without a priori knowledge, it is able to make flexible partitions of a finite data set, and it is an adaptive approach able to recognize nonstationary biomedical signals, such as EEG data. 16 For these reasons, in this study, EEG data were recognized by FCM clustering.

To assess the performance of the proposed system, band power features, k-means clustering and linear discriminant analysis (LDA) classifier were compared. Results show satisfactory classification accuracy, and area under the receiver operating characteristics curve (AUC) for the proposed wavelet-based AM features and FCM clustering. It shows that there is great potential for the proposed methods in BCI applications.

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p: A flowchart of the EEG analysis for the single-trial discriminant is illustrated in Figure 1. The procedure consists of feature extraction and FCM clustering. We extract features with the AM method from the DWT data, and the FCM is then applied for the discriminant.

sec.title: Data Acquisition
sec.p: The EEG signals were recorded from 7 untrained participants (6 males and 1 female, 3 left-handed and 4 right-handed) in a shielded room using 7 silver/silver chloride electrodes. As illustrated in Figure 2, they included 5 scalp EEG channels (C3, C5, FC3, C1, and CP3. These five channels were selected since they can be further processed by surface Laplacian filtering as discussed in the next section. One EMG channel for monitoring right muscle activity, and 1 channel on the forehead to record possible electro-oculogram (EOG) artifacts and eye blinks during the experiment. 17 All electrodes were referenced to the A1 lead at the left earlobe. Before being sampled at the rate of 256 Hz, the EEG data were filtered by an analog band-pass filter with cutoff frequencies at 0.5 Hz and 100 Hz, and amplified by a multiple of 10 000. During the experiments, each participant was asked to perform 2 trials in each test, which included left finger lifting and resting. Each trial was 10 seconds in length, so it took 20 seconds to complete a test. In each lifting trial, the first 4 seconds were quiet and then an acoustic stimulus was given as a cue to signify the beginning of left finger lifting. At the same time, each participant was asked to execute finger lifting. An example of a test is shown in Figure 3A. We recorded 60 tests for each participant, and thus there were 120 trials for each participant. No trials were removed during the EEG data processing stage. Data segments for finger lifting were acquired from −2 to 2 seconds, where second 0 stands for the trigger of movement by detecting the peak EMG signal after linear envelope processing. (Only the data recorded between −2 and 2 seconds were considered to be event related.) Data segments for finger resting were randomly acquired from 4-second windows within the finger resting sections in each trial.

sec.title: Wavelet transform
sec.p: Before classification, feature extraction is performed on the event-related windows rather than directly classifying the native EEG data without feature extraction. In this study, we first band-pass filtered the windows to the wide frequency range that contains all mu and beta rhythmic components using a Butterworth band-pass filter. We then performed the Daubechies discrete wavelet transform (DWT) 19 on the filtered windows. We chose the Daubechies wavelet due to the special characteristic that Daubechies family wavelets are compactly supported with extreme phase and highest number of vanishing moments for a given support width.

Multiresolution analysis decomposed a signal into numerous details at various resolutions, where each resolution represented a class of distinct physical characteristics within the signal. More specifically, a signal was characterized with the formulation by decomposing it into sub-bands, each of which could be treated individually based on its characteristics. sec.title: Fuzzy c-means Clustering
sec.p:

,
22 assigns the sample with a number between 0 and 1 described as a membership function. In this article, fuzzy clustering method classified feature vectors extracted from the original EEG data and recognized complicated brain mental tasks, such as left finger lifting and resting.

sec.title: Performance and Statistical Evaluation for Wavelet-Based AM Features
sec.p:
We can expect higher classification accuracy if extracted features are better. In this study, we combine DWT with AM to extract multiscale envelope features. As the DWT is often implemented by a pyramid-structured filter bank that is very efficient in data representation, it is an efficient and structured approach to ERP representation. 23
,
25 Moreover, all kinds of feature extraction methods have been proposed. The band power is common among them, so band power features are compared with the wavelet-based AM features.

The classification tests for EEG data are carried out using 5-fold cross validation in this study. More specifically, the data set for each participant is divided into 5 subsets, and the following procedure is repeated 5 times. Each time, 1 of the 5 subsets is used as the test set and the other 4 are used as training set. The average recognition rate is immediately evaluated across all 5 folds. In addition to classification accuracy, the receiver operating characteristics (ROC) curve is another popular approach to evaluate the performance of a method. 26 An ROC curve is obtained by plotting all sensitivity values (true positive fraction) on the y axis against their equivalent specificity values (false positive fraction) on the x axis for all available thresholds of classified results of test data. The area under the ROC curve (AUC) is usually taken to be an important index because it provides a single measure of overall accuracy that is not dependent upon a particular threshold. This study evaluates the performance of proposed system by means of both the classification accuracy and AUC.

An experiment is performed for evaluating the performance of wavelet-based AM features. Tables 1 and 2 show the comparisons of classification accuracy and AUC between band power and wavelet-based AM features under the FCM clustering. These 2 features are applied to the same clustering. In other words, the listed values demonstrate only the deviations of performance between different features. Overall, the average recognition rate and AUC for band power features are 72.8% and 0.70, respectively, whereas using wavelet-based AM as features yielded the better average rate (81.7%) and AUC (0.77), the difference being 8.9% and 0.07, respectively. In addition, we observe that the wavelet-based AM features give the best results for 6 participants, whereas band power features lead to those for only 1 participant. It indicates that the wavelet-based AM features can obtain the better performance in BCI applications.

sec.p: Moreover, 2-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) is performed to verify whether the comparisons between band power and wavelet-based AM features are significantly different. The results indicate that the differences between them are significant in both classification accuracy (P value .0345) and AUC (P value .0362). That is, wavelet-based AM features are significantly better than band power features in BCI applications.

sec.title: Performance and Statistical Evaluation for FCM Clustering
sec.p: An unsupervised FCM method is proposed for left finger lifting and resting classification from single-trial EEG data in this study. The FCM algorithm is implemented to recognize left finger lifting and resting EEG data without any training in advance. As FCM clustering is an unsupervised approach, it is adopted to automatically classify wavelet-based AM features into 2 clusters, left finger lifting and resting. Some attractive properties of FCM clustering are summarized as follows: first, FCM clustering is an unsupervised method, discriminating the data without labeling them before training; second, FCM clustering is capable of making flexible partitions of a finite data set; and third, FCM clustering is a robust approach suitable for the classification of nonstationary biomedical signals. Therefore, we use FCM clustering for the classification of EEG data in this study.

We evaluate the performance of FCM clustering. Tables 3 and 4 list the comparisons of classification accuracy and AUC under the same AM features among LDA, k-means, and FCM. The results show that the average accuracy for LDA is the worst, whereas that for FCM is the best. The average AUC for FCM is the best, while that for k-means is the worst. Classification accuracy and AUC with FCM obtains the best results for all participants. Accordingly, the results denote that the FCM is better than the LDA and k-means in EEG classification.

sec.p: In addition, 2-way ANOVA and multiple comparison tests determined whether these 3 classifiers are significantly different. The results reveal that there are significant differences in both classification accuracy and AUC: “between LDA and FCM” (P values .0084 and .0105) and “between k-means and FCM” (P values .0066 and .0096). Hence, the FCM is the best of these 3 classifiers in BCI applications.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: We have proposed an analysis system for single-trial EEG classification. The system that contains wavelet-based AM features and the FCM clustering is present for the discriminant of left finger lifting and resting. The features are extracted by AM method from the DWT data. They are good features that can improve the classification of mental tasks. The FCM is then used for the recognition of EEG data. Results indicate that the proposed methods are better in classification accuracy and AUC in comparison with band power features, k-means, and LDA classifier. We will develop some more powerful features and classifiers to further enhance the performance.
